abstract.p: Samuel W Gelfman letter on May 23 article on Mir space station

block.p: Nowhere in ''Proud Russia Keeps Mir Aloft'' (May 23) did anyone speak of Mir's historical, archaeological or aesthetic importance.

The news recently has been full of Viking voyages to Vinland and restoration of their sod homes; the preservation of Roman mosaics, soon to be inundated under a Turkish reservoir; and the opening of newly discovered Egyptian tombs.
Nowhere in ''Proud Russia Keeps Mir Aloft'' (May 23) did anyone speak of Mir's historical, archaeological or aesthetic importance.

The news recently has been full of Viking voyages to Vinland and restoration of their sod homes; the preservation of Roman mosaics, soon to be inundated under a Turkish reservoir; and the opening of newly discovered Egyptian tombs.

Governments, our own included, happily contribute to all these projects. Yet the maintenance of Mir -- the Nina, Pinta and Santa Maria of space vehicles -- depends, it seems, on whether a shaky commercial venture can hit the basics of its business plan.
One official begrudges that the Russians, behind in their financing of the International Space Station, always seem to have a little extra money around for Mir. And well they should, as should we.

Mir is an international milestone. A global Eiffel Tower. A cosmic Sistine ceiling. ''Look at this, girls and boys,'' the third millennium third-grade teacher will say on their tour of the global equivalent of the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum, ''the very first space station we humans put up there over 1,000 years ago.''
And they'll respond, ''Yech, I'd hate to have to live in anything that gross!''
Save Mir? Of course save Mir. What would we give to have had someone save the Colossus of Rhodes or Alexander's Library?
